Prominent changes included more [[qualified majority voting]] in the [[Council of the European Union|Council of Ministers]], increased involvement of the [[European Parliament]] in the legislative process through extended [[Codecision procedure|codecision]] with the Council of Ministers, eliminating the [[Three pillars of the European Union|pillar system]] and the creation of a [[President of the European Council]] with a term of two and a half years and a [[High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy]] to present a united position on EU policies. The Treaty of Lisbon will also make the Union's human rights charter, the [[Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union|Charter of Fundamental Rights]], legally binding. The Lisbon Treaty also leads to an increase in the voting weight of the UK in the [[Treaty_of_Lisbon#Council|Council of the European Union]] from 8.4% to 12.4%. In July 2008, the Labour government under [[Gordon Brown]] approved the treaty and the Queen ratified it.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7511281.stm UK ratifies the EU Lisbon Treaty] [[BBC]]</ref>
===Devolution for Scotland and Wales=== {{main|Scottish devolution|Welsh devolution}} On 11 September 1997, (on the 700th anniversary of the Scottish victory over the English at the [[Battle of Stirling Bridge]]), a [[scottish devolution referendum, 1997|referendum]] was held on establishing a devolved [[Scottish Parliament]]. This resulted in an overwhelming 'yes' vote both to establishing the parliament and granting it limited tax varying powers. Two weeks later, a [[Welsh devolution referendum, 1997|referendum]] in Wales on establishing a [[Welsh Assembly]] was also approved but with a very narrow majority. The first elections were held, and these bodies began to operate, in 1999. The creation of these bodies has widened the differences between the [[Countries of the United Kingdom]], especially in areas like [[Healthcare in the United Kingdom|healthcare]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/7586147.stm 'Huge contrasts' in devolved NHS] BBC News, 28 August 2008</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/7149423.stm NHS now four different systems] [[BBC]] 2 January 2008</ref> It has also brought to the fore the so-called [[West Lothian question]] which is a complaint that devolution for Scotland and Wales but not England has created a situation where all the MPs in the UK parliament can vote on matters affecting England alone but on those same matters Scotland and Wales can make their own decisions.
==21st century== === War in Afghanistan and Iraq, and terrorist attacks at home=== In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 General Election]], the Labour Party won a second successive victory, though voter turnout dropped to the lowest level for more than 80 years.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/vote2001/hi/english/newsid_1376000/1376575.stm Turnout 'at 80-year low'] news.bbc.co.uk, 8 June 2001</ref> Later that year, the [[September 11th attacks]] in the [[United States]] led to American President [[George W. Bush]] launching the [[War on Terror]], beginning with the [[Afghanistan War (2001-present)|invasion of]] [[Afghanistan]] aided by British troops in October 2001. Thereafter, with the US focus shifting to [[Iraq]], Tony Blair decided to support the [[United States]] in the 2003 [[invasion of Iraq]], despite huge anti-war marches held in London and Glasgow. Forty-six thousand British troops, one-third of the total strength of the [[British Army]]'s land forces, were deployed to assist with the invasion of Iraq and thereafter [[British Armed Forces|British armed forces]] were responsible for security in southern Iraq in the run-up to the [[Politics of Iraq|Iraqi elections]] of January 2005.
The Labour Party won the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]] and a third consecutive term in office despite support dropping to just 35% of those who voted.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/vote2005/html/scoreboard.stm Full national scoreboard] news.bbc.co.uk, 24 June 2005</ref> However the effects of the [[War on Terror]] following 9/11 increased the threat of international terrorists plotting attacks against the UK. On 7 July 2005, [[7 July 2005 London bombings|a series of four suicide bombings]] struck London's [[public transport]] system during the morning [[rush hour]]. The four incidents killed a total of 52 commuters, in addition to the four bombers. Later in 2007, Muslim extremists drove a [[Jeep Cherokee (XJ)|Jeep Cherokee]], loaded with propane canisters, into the glass doors of [[Glasgow International Airport]], setting it ablaze. The intention was to drive the vehicle into the airport and have the car explode inside the terminal, but the car was hindered by security [[bollard]]s, causing no civilian deaths.
===Nationalist government in Scotland=== 2007 saw the first ever election victory for the pro-independence [[Scottish National Party]] (SNP) in the [[Scottish Parliament Election, 2007|Scottish Parliament elections]]. They formed a [[minority government]] with plans to hold a referendum before 2011 to seek a mandate "to negotiate with the Government of the United Kingdom to achieve [[Scottish Independence|independence for Scotland]]."<ref>[http://www.scotland.gov.uk/Publications/2007/08/13103747/10 Choosing Scotland's Future: A National Conversation: Independence and Responsibility in the Modern World, Annex B Draft Referendum (Scotland) Bill] The Scottish Government, Publications</ref> Most opinion polls show minority support for independence, although support varies depending on the nature of the question. The response of the unionist parties was to establish the [[Commission on Scottish Devolution|Calman Commission]] to examine further [[devolution]] of powers,<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/7129899.stm MSPs back devolution review body] BBC News, 6 December 2007.</ref> a position that had the support of the Prime Minister.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7249002.stm PM backs Scottish powers review] BBC News, 17 February 2008.</ref>
Responding to the findings of the review, the UK government announced on 25 November 2009, that new powers would be devolved to the [[Scottish Government]], notably on how it can raise tax and carry out capital borrowing, and the running of [[Scottish Parliament elections]].<ref name=BBC25Nov09NewPowersAfterCalman/> These proposals were detailed in a [[white paper]] setting out a [[Scotland Bill 2010-11|new Scotland Bill]], to become law before the 2015 Holyrood elections.<ref name=BBC25Nov09NewPowersAfterCalman/> The proposal was criticised by the UK parliament opposition parties for not proposing to implement any changes before the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|next general election]]. Scottish Constitution Minister [[Michael Russell (politician)|Michael Russell]] criticised the white paper, calling it "flimsy" and stating that their proposed [[Referendum (Scotland) Bill, 2010]], whose own white paper was to be published five days later, would be "more substantial".<ref name=BBC25Nov09NewPowersAfterCalman>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/8377028.stm |title=New Holyrood powers planned after Calman review |publisher=BBC News |date=2009-11-25 |accessdate=2009-11-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5lfp99q0W |archivedate=2009-11-30 }}</ref> According to ''[[The Independent]]'', the Calman Review white paper proposals fall short of what would normally be seen as requiring a referendum.<ref name=Independent30Nov09SNPReveals>{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/snp-reveals-vision-for-independence-referendum-1831469.html |title=SNP reveals vision for independence referendum |publisher=The Independent |date=2009-11-30 |accessdate=2009-11-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5lfqjoj1A |archivedate=2009-11-30 |location=London |first=Joe |last=Quinn}}</ref>
The [[Scottish Parliament general election, 2011|2011 election]] saw a decisive victory for the SNP which was able to form a majority government intent on delivering a referendum on independence.<ref>{{Citation |last = A. Black |title = Scottish election: SNP profile |journal = BBC News|date = 18 May 2011 |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-13315752| archiveurl =http://www.webcitation.org/5zBnzdI2O| archivedate =3 June 2011}}.</ref> Within hours of the victory, Prime Minister David Cameron guaranteed that the UK government would not put any legal or political obstacles in the way of such a referendum.<ref>[http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2011/may/08/cameron-green-light-scottish-referendum Scottish independence: Cameron gives green light to referendum] guardian.co.uk, 8 May 2011</ref> Some unionist politicians, including former Labour First Minister [[Henry McLeish]], have responded to the situation by arguing that Scotland should be offered '[[devo-max]]' as an alternative to independence,<ref>[http://www.holyrood.com/articles/2011/10/17/mcleish-reiterates-support-for-devo-max/ McLeish reiterates support for devo-max] holyrood.com, 17 October 2011</ref> and First Minister Alex Salmond has signalled his willingness to include it on the referendum ballot paper.<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/news/salmond_gives_backing_to_devo_max_ballot_choice_1_1925360 Salmond gives backing to âdevo maxâ ballot choice] The Scotsman, 22 October 2011</ref>
===The 2008 economic crisis=== In the wake of the global [[economic crisis of 2008]], the United Kingdom economy contracted, experiencing negative economic growth throughout 2009. The announcement in November 2008 that the economy had shrunk for the first time since late 1992 brought an end to 16 years of continuous economic growth. Causes included an end to the easy credit of the preceding years, reduction in consumption and substantial depreciation of sterling (which fell 25% against the euro between January 2008 and January 2009),<ref>[http://www.oanda.com/convert/fxhistory FXHistory: historical currency exchange rates] From â¬1 => Â£0.73650 to â¬1 => 0.9690</ref> leading to increased import costs, notably of oil.
On 8 October 2008, the [[British Government]] announced a [[2008 United Kingdom bank rescue package|bank rescue package]] of around Â£500 billion<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/gordon-brown/4961897/Gordon-Brown-should-say-sorry-over-economy-minister-says.html |title=Gordon Brown should say 'sorry' |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2009-03-09 |accessdate=2009-03-09 | location=London}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> ($850 billion at the time). The plan comprised three parts.: Â£200 billion to be made available to the banks in the [[Bank of England]]'s Special Liquidity Scheme; the Government was to increase the banks' market capitalization, through the Bank Recapitalization Fund, with an initial Â£25 billion and another Â£25 billion to be provided if needed; and the Government was to temporarily underwrite any eligible lending between British banks up to around Â£250 billion. With the UK officially coming out of recession in the fourth quarter of 2009 - ending six consecutive quarters of economic decline - the Bank of England decided against further [[quantitative easing]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/8496830.stm Bank of England's time-out for quantitative easing plan] news.bbc.co.uk, 4 February 2010</ref>
===The 2010 coalition government=== The [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|United Kingdom General Election]] of 6 May 2010 resulted in the first [[hung parliament]] since 1974, with the Conservative Party winning the largest number of seats, but falling short of the 326 seats required for an overall majority. Following this, the Conservatives and the [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] agreed to form the first [[Cameron Ministry|coalition government]] for the UK since the end of the Second World War, with [[David Cameron]] becoming Prime Minister and [[Nick Clegg]] Deputy Prime Minister.
Under the coalition government, [[Royal Air Force|British military aircraft]] participated in the [[United Nations|UN]]-mandated [[2011 military intervention in Libya|intervention]] in the [[2011 Libyan civil war]], flying a total of 3,000 air [[sortie]]s against forces loyal to the Libyan dictator [[Muammar Gaddafi]] between March and October 2011.<ref>[http://www.raf.mod.uk/news/Libya-OpELLAMY.cfm RAF.mod.uk - Operation Ellamy]. Retrieved 2011-10-20.</ref><ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15502414 "UK military starting Libya return".] BBC, 28 October 2011. Retrieved 2011-10-29.</ref> 2011 also saw England suffer [[2011 England riots|unprecedented rioting]] in its major cities in early August, killing five people and causing over Â£200 million worth of property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abi.org.uk/Media/Releases/2011/08/UK__Insurance_Industry_welcomes_Prime_Ministers_Compensation_Scheme_announcement_and_pledges_help_to_make_the_scheme_work_.aspx|title=UK Insurance Industry welcomes Prime Minister's Compensation Scheme announcement and pledges help to make the scheme work|publisher=Association of British Insurers|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref>
In late October 2011, the [[Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 2011|Heads of Government]] of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]] voted to grant gender equality in the [[Line of succession to the British throne|British royal succession]], ending the male-preference [[primogeniture]] that was mandated by the [[Act of Settlement 1701|1701 Act of Settlement]].<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2054467/UK-royal-succession-laws-Commonwealth-agrees-historic-change-sex-equality.html?ito=feeds-newsxml "Commonwealth agrees historic change to give sex equality in Royal succession"]. ''[[Daily Mail]]'', 28 October 2011. Retrieved 2011-10-29.</ref> The amendment also ended the ban on the monarch marrying a [[Catholic]].<ref>[http://ncronline.org/news/global/commonwealth-lift-law-banning-monarchs-marrying-catholics "British monarchs can soon marry Catholics"]. ''National Catholic Reporter'', 28 October 2011. Retrieved 2011-10-29.</ref>

==Notes== <sup>1</sup>    The terms "United Kingdom" and "United Kingdom of Great Britain" were used in the [[Treaty of Union]] and the [[Act of Union 1707|1707 Acts of Union]]. However,the actual ''name'' of the new state was "Great Britain".<br> <sup>2</sup>    The name "Great Britain" (then spelled "Great Brittaine") was first used by James VI/I in October 1604, who indicated that henceforth he and his successors would be viewed as Kings of Great Britain, not Kings of England and Scotland. However the name was not applied to the ''state'' as a unit; both England and Scotland continued to be governed independently. Its validity as a name of the Crown is also questioned, given that monarchs continued using separate ordinals (e.g., James VI/I, James VII/II) in England and Scotland. To avoid confusion, historians generally avoid using the term "King of Great Britain" until 1707 and instead to match the ordinal usage call the monarchs kings or queens of England and Scotland. Separate ordinals were abandoned when the two states merged in accordance with the [[Acts of Union 1707|1707 Acts of Union]], with subsequent monarchs using ordinals apparently based on English not Scottish history (it might be argued that the monarchs have simply taken the higher ordinal, which to date has always been English). One example is Queen [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom]], who is referred to as being "the Second" even though there never was an Elizabeth I of Scotland or Great Britain. Thus the term "Great Britain" is generally used from 1707.<br> <sup>3</sup>    The number changed several times between 1801 and 1922.<br> <sup>4</sup>    The Anglo-Irish Treaty was ratified by (i) The British Parliament (Commons, Lords & [[Royal Assent]]), (ii) DÃ¡il Ãireann, and the (iii) "at a meeting of members of the Parliament elected for constituencies in Southern Ireland", (though not the [[House of Commons of Southern Ireland]] â see [[House of Commons of Southern Ireland#"Meeting" approves Treaty|this]]), the Treaty thus being ratified under both British and Irish constitutional theory.
